questions.question:
Question 1: A 27-year-old man had an RTA resulting in the following gait abnormality. What is the largest 
part of the affected structure?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-traumatic cerebellar ataxia presenting with 
impaired balance. The largest part of the affected structure i.e. the cerebellum is the middle lobe, 
also known as the posterior lobe. The gait shown in the above video is a cerebellar ataxic 
gait. Here, the patient is seen attempting tandem walking and displaying improper heel-toe 
coordination, erratic foot placement, and truncal swaying. The cerebellum consists of two hemispheres (right and left) joined by a median vermis. It is 
divided into three lobes: • Anterior lobe - lies superiorly above the primary fissure • Middle lobe - lies inferiorly below the primary fissure • Flocculonodular lobe - lies posterior to the uvulonodular fissure It has two surfaces, superior and inferior, separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the 
other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles. 428 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following represents the arrangement of cerebellar nuclei from lateral to medial:
questions.explanation:
The arrangement of cerebellar nuclei from lateral to medial is dentate, emboliform, globose, and 
fastigial.

Question 4: Cerebellar glomeruli are seen in which layer of the cerebellar cortex? 423 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: Cerebellar glomeruli are seen in the granular layer (layer B) of the cerebellar cortex.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 52-year-old man presents with ataxia-telangiectasia. Which of the following is an excitatory 
cell lost in this disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ataxia-telangiectasia is characterized by progressive neuronal degeneration with a loss of Purkinje 
and granule cells in the cerebellum. The granule cells are the only excitatory cells in the cerebellar 
cortex. 430 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A man presented with tremors caused due to progressive degeneration of the cells that form 
the output of the cerebellar cortex. Which of the following cells are affected?
questions.explanation:
The tremors are caused due to progressive degeneration of the Purkinje cells that form the output 
of the cerebellar cortex. They form the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex. The output of the whole cerebellum is from the deep cerebellar nuclei namely fastigial, globose, 
emboliform and dentate.

questions.question:
Question 8: The following slide from a rabies patient shows inclusion bodies in the Purkinje cells 
receiving input from:
questions.explanation:
The given slide shows Negri bodies, which are eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions found in the 
neurons of the Purkinje cells in a patient with rabies. The input to the Purkinje cells of the 
cerebellum come from the climbing fibers. The image given below shows Negri bodies.

Question 9: A patient recovering from COVID-19 presented with sudden onset slurred speech and 
difficulty walking. On examination, cerebellar signs are positive. What is true about the 
affected circuitry?

options.a: Climbing and mossy fibers are inhibitory and use GABA as the neurotransmitter.
options.b: Mossy fibers end by forming a synapse with dendrites of Purkinje cells.
options.c: All climbing fibers originate from the contralateral inferior olivary nucleus.
options.d: Efferent fibers from all the cerebellar nuclei leave the cerebellum through superior cerebellar

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute viral cerebellitis secondary to COVID-19. The true 
statement regarding the cerebellar circuitry is that that all climbing fibres originate from the 
contralateral inferior olivary nucleus. 431 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Climbing and mossy fibers are excitatory and use glutamate and aspartate as the 
neurotransmitters. Option B: Mossy fibers terminate on the granule cells forming glomeruli. Option D: Efferents of the cerebellum pass through the superior and inferior cerebellar peduncles.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient with acoustic neuroma presented with ataxia. MRI brain revealed the tumour 
impinging on the middle cerebellar peduncle. What fibres are transmitted from this 
structure?
questions.explanation: The middle cerebellar peduncle transmits fibers of pontocerebellar pathway.

questions.question: Question 11: Purkinje cells of cerebellum relay into
questions.explanation:
Purkinje cells of the cerebellum relay into the dentate nucleus which is one of the deep cerebellar 
nuclei. The input to the Purkinje cells come from the climbing fibres. The output of Purkinje cells is 
inhibitory to the deep cerebellar nuclei. Options A and B: Caudate and lentiform nuclei are part of the basal ganglia. Option D: Red nucleus receives afferents from the cerebellum and plays a role in modulating 
signals to the upper motor neurons of the cerebral cortex.

questions.question:
Question 12: 426 
Sold by @itachibot A patient was diagnosed with glioblastoma multiforme involving the inferior cerebellar 
peduncle. All of the following tracts may be involved by the tumor except:
questions.explanation:
The anterior spinocerebellar tract does not pass through the inferior cerebellar peduncle. It enters 
the cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle. Glioblastoma multiforme is the most malignant and frequently occurring type of primary 
astrocytomas. It has the worst long-term prognosis (median survival of roughly 1 year).

questions.question: Question 13: Fibers from the marked structure terminate at which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The peduncle highlighted in the image is the superior cerebellar peduncle. The superior cerebellar 
peduncle includes fibers from deep cerebellar nuclei that project to the brainstem, red nucleus, 
and thalamus. It also contains the ventral spinocerebellar tract fibers. The superior cerebellar peduncle contains all the efferent fibers from the dentate, emboliform, 
and the globose nuclei, and a small fascicle from the fastigial nucleus. Its fibers decussate in the 
caudal mesencephalon and are destined to synapse in the contralateral red nucleus and 
thalamus. The middle cerebellar peduncle contains only afferent fibers from the contralateral 
pontine nuclei. The inferior cerebellar peduncle is a mixture of afferent fibers from the brainstem 
and spinal cord and efferent fibers to the vestibular nuclei. The image below summarizes the various tracts in the cerebellar unit. 432 
Sold by @itachibot The cerebellum consists of two hemispheres (right and left) joined by a median vermis. It is 
divided into three lobes:- • Anterior lobe - lies superiorly above the primary fissure • Middle lobe - lies inferiorly below the primary fissure. It is the largest lobe. It is also called the 
posterior lobe. • Flocculonodular lobe - lies posterior to the uvulonodular fissure It has two surfaces - superior and inferior separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the 
other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles • Superior cerebellar peduncle -connecting to the midbrain • Middle cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the pons • Inferior cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the medulla oblongata

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient presented with clinical features of ataxia and incoordination. This is due to 
thrombosis of which artery?
questions.explanation:
Thrombosis of the superior cerebellar artery causes cerebellar lesion which presents with ataxia 
and incoordination. Blood supply of cerebellum: • Superior cerebellar artery • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery 433
